hey all, anybody here a google analytics expert? 

we’ve setup goals + events. problem is we’re seeing abysmal goal conversions. (our content strategy is conversion-driven). would love a seasoned set of eyes to look over our setup and if it’s incorrect, help fix it. (paid gig ofc) 

referrals are most appreciated. thanks all!

text: Outside of a spreadsheet (img attached) what would you include in this information for a content strategy with accompanying content briefs? I want to see if I've missed anything off as part of this process.

elements.text: Outside of a spreadsheet (img attached) what would you include in this information for a content strategy with accompanying content briefs? I want to see if I've missed anything off as part of this process.

text:
We try to give a higher level breakdown of the hubs of content where we drew the keywords from. Not sure if that's part of what you do before this point in the process; we just typically include that in the strategy.

The other thing I'd add is a content calendar with a breakdown of which pages will be created in what order and on what week/day.

text:
_Not sure if I should post this in <#C022W2V1Q0Y|-seo-talk> so let me know if that’s a better place for my question_

I have a list of keywords I collected (using SEMrush) for a blog post topic I’d like to post about. It’s a relatively large list (75 keywords) and I’m stuck at where to start with choosing which keywords to use in my post. Any suggestions?

elements.text: Not sure if I should post this in
so let me know if that’s a better place for my question

I have a list of keywords I collected (using SEMrush) for a blog post topic I’d like to post about. It’s a relatively large list (75 keywords) and I’m stuck at where to start with choosing which keywords to use in my post. Any suggestions?

text:
You can leverage Semrush's writing assistant to help you out. It can suggest other keywords to use.

If you have the budget for it, a tool like Topic can help too and track you keyword usage over time (along with recommending the keywords to use)

elements.text:
You can leverage Semrush's writing assistant to help you out. It can suggest other keywords to use.

If you have the budget for it, a tool like Topic can help too and track you keyword usage over time (along with recommending the keywords to use)

text: there are some cool new tools out there now, which could be useful depending on the subject matter you cover. <https://rightmetric.co/> and <http://sacra.com|sacra.com> come to mind

attachments.title: RightMetric | Actionable Consumer & Competitive Insights For Marketers
attachments.text: Everything you need to know about digital marketing in an easily searchable library. Our data-backed case studies offer insights and advice on what's already working across the digital landscape, so you can be sure you’re making the right decision for your brand.
attachments.fallback: RightMetric | Actionable Consumer & Competitive Insights For Marketers

elements.text: there are some cool new tools out there now, which could be useful depending on the subject matter you cover.
and
sacra.com
come to mind

text:
First, I'd start by identifying the goal of the content? Is it informational, transactional, where does it fall in your marketing funnel? From there I would look at your list and see which keywords match that goal/intent of the content.

Then I'd look at what competitors are doing for that smaller list of keywords. I'd also look at the search volume and kw difficulty in SEMRush (kw difficulty is vague in my opinion but can be helpful to prioritize which keyword)

elements.text:
First, I'd start by identifying the goal of the content? Is it informational, transactional, where does it fall in your marketing funnel? From there I would look at your list and see which keywords match that goal/intent of the content.

Then I'd look at what competitors are doing for that smaller list of keywords. I'd also look at the search volume and kw difficulty in SEMRush (kw difficulty is vague in my opinion but can be helpful to prioritize which keyword)

text:
<@U01KGTNFLVA> Thanks for the response!

This post is both informational and can lead to conversions. All the keywords can be found in some competing posts, so that doesn’t narrow it down for me. I don’t know how to figure out which keywords are worth including - i.e. how to calculate the balance between keyword difficulty and search volume.

Does anyone have a process that they follow?

elements.text:

text: Hey all! Wondering if there are any marketing automation tools you would recommend? Apologies if this is the wrong channel. But I am responsible for marketing automation, since email is one of our primary content distribution channels, and we are a small team. We currently use ActiveCampaign, but are looking to replace.

elements.text: Hey all! Wondering if there are any marketing automation tools you would recommend? Apologies if this is the wrong channel. But I am responsible for marketing automation, since email is one of our primary content distribution channels, and we are a small team. We currently use ActiveCampaign, but are looking to replace.

text: I usually go from ActiveCampaign to HubSpot (if the budget allows for it)

elements.text: I usually go from ActiveCampaign to HubSpot (if the budget allows for it)

text: Drip is a pretty cool one. But for small teams, Hubspot is nice. Having your CRM, email, chatbots, workflows, and web analytics in one place makes measuring performance a little easier

elements.text: Drip is a pretty cool one. But for small teams, Hubspot is nice. Having your CRM, email, chatbots, workflows, and web analytics in one place makes measuring performance a little easier

text:
If you want something super advanced and you can pretty much anything you can dream of: *ActiveCampaign*

If you want basic automations & super easy UI: *ConvertKit*

elements.text: If you want something super advanced and you can pretty much anything you can dream of:
ActiveCampaign
If you want basic automations & super easy UI:
ConvertKit

text:
A few ways to think about this:

• if you were writing a post about choosing a shower head, what would you want to see? What would you look for? That will give you a sense of the structure of the piece. 
• From there, look at competing content ranking for the terms you want to rank for. What info do they include? What keywords does it seem they’re using? 
• From there, think about the structure of your piece, ‘bucket’ the keywords you’ve identified into the sections, and that’ll give you a sense of which keywords to use where.

elements.text: A few ways to think about this:
if you were writing a post about choosing a shower head, what would you want to see? What would you look for? That will give you a sense of the structure of the piece.
From there, look at competing content ranking for the terms you want to rank for. What info do they include? What keywords does it seem they’re using?
From there, think about the structure of your piece, ‘bucket’ the keywords you’ve identified into the sections, and that’ll give you a sense of which keywords to use where.
